fuel_ccp/fernet_utils.py.message:
in python3 .sort method was removed. Instead of it, sorted() should be used. Like this:

 number_keys = sorted(number_keys, key=int)
in python3 this won't work because number_keys has type "dict_keys". number_keys need to become list first.

nope, won't work. sorted() sorts list not in place, but creates a new list (in other words, it is non-destructible operation). Should be:

number_keys = sorted(number_keys, key=int)
i think that sorted() will return a list and this coercion will not be necessary, so please disregard the previous comment.

tools/oslo_debug_helper.message: What sets PYTHON outside of this script?

What if we made -p an explicit option on the script and set $PYTHON based on that?  Then instead of setting PACKAGENAME and TEST_DIR above this, we set them below only if TEST_DIR isn't already set.  That way if a user specified a different python we'll use it to run setup.py, and as an added bonus we don't make the unnecessary call at all if the user passed in an explicit test dir.

Edit: As much as I have an aversion to input environment variables, looking at the next file in this change I see we were already doing that.  Since that file wasn't using getopts already, maybe we should just stick with the $PYTHON pattern.

I keep this to ensure all print use the function format
And this one?  I'd rather avoid changing behaviors like this for no reason.

I have the habbit to automatically add these future in all python 2/3 code, to maximize compatibility and portability.

This duplicates the -v shortname from above.  And do we even need this opt?  Isn't the whole point of this command to do the tag?  If you don't want this behavior the solution seems to be "don't run it". :-)

I don't know how to choose between generating a v-version or not. Does the dev wants `1.0.0` or `v1.0.01 (like I want, actually).

It does not conflict with the general -v, since it is the argument of a subcommand. If `-v` would be `--verbose` (like it is on other commands), something like `mycmd -v mycommand -v` would do exactly what is expected).

I remove the short version for clarity sake. But I would like to keep this option, since I have no other way to detect when to generate a v-version.
*minimum

I think I'd prefer to invert this logic.  I'm fine with having the ability to just display the command, but if you're running this command then that seems like sufficient indication that you wanted to actually do the tag.

How about we change this to --dry-run (perhaps with a -n shortname like git-review) and skip the actual execution of git if that's passed?
agree
I did not found a way to retrieve the current package name so I need to ask the user to provide it

nit: the releae_version variable probably should be release_version (with the S in release)

Done
Are we ever going to tag in any way other than git? Should the command just be "tag"?
Done
Is the current package something other than the dist name for the code in the current repository?

The command "python setup.py --name" will give it to you, but I don't know where you would get it from the setuptools data structure.

Why do you need to know the name of the package to tag it?

> Just to call _get_info I need to have somehow the name of the
 > package.

OK. No other commands require the user to pass the value on the command line, so at the very least we should do whatever those commands do to find the value.

 > Maybe pbr tag is not the right place to add this command. Maybe
 > letting the user get the tag with `python setup.py
 > show_release_version` and leaving the git tag command to himself it
 > enough.

The more I think about it, the less I like the tag command. I still like the show_release_version command.

We have been trying to make the pbr layer thinner. Adding a tagging command seems like it will eventually require us to add lots of the options available to git-tag, just to provide a minor convenience (signed tags or not signed tags? which key for a signed tag? how about a message? etc.). Having a pbr command that computes and shows the next version is the useful bit, and I think we should stop with that.

 > I still prefer doing:
 > 
 > pbr pbr mypackage --v-version
 > 
 > Even if it would be cooler to do:
 > 
 > pbr pbr --v-version

I'm not sure why the pbr value is repeated on those command lines and I still think there must be a way for us to get the name without the user passing it. We do that all over the place, right?

I *do* like making this a pbr command instead of a setuptools command.

  pbr show-next-version

Just to call _get_info I need to have somehow the name of the package.

Calling 'python setup.py --name' would be the same than just reading setup.cfg in the current folder, it would work, but it would requires to have 'pbr' command executed at the root of the project. I have no pbl with it.

Maybe pbr tag is not the right place to add this command. Maybe letting the user get the tag with `python setup.py show_release_version` and leaving the git tag command to himself it enough.
But on the other hand, setup.py might display some garbage such as:

    $ python setup.py show_release_version                                                                                        
    /usr/.../distutils/dist.py:261: UserWarning: Unknown distribution option: 'long_description_content_type'
      warnings.warn(msg)
    running show_release_version
   4.0.5

So one would need to tail it in command such as:

    VERSION=$(python setup.py show_release_version 2> /dev/null | tail -n 1)
    git tag -m "Release $VERSION" v$VERSION

I still prefer doing:

    pbr pbr mypackage --v-version

Even if it would be cooler to do:

    pbr pbr --v-version

I did not found an easy way of getting the current package name. When we start the pbr command, even within a virtualenv, I do not see how to retrieve the name of the "current" package, looking for a "setup.cfg" in the current folder ?

That's why I added a command `python setup.py release_version` in which i have all the information.

I'm not sure it's necessary to parameterize this given that it's a hard-coded string. Maybe just put the command name directly into the error string.

Also, I think maybe the purpose of this function changed since it was written. It no longer returns the entire package config, just the package name. I think it should be renamed and the docstring updated to reflect that.
This seems problematic since the caller doesn't check the return value. I think we should raise an exception in this case.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: Note that this is a separate bug, but something that came up this week so it was fresh in my mind.
I think this is a definite *yes* regardless of what we do here, log or fail I mean. Otherwise we'll orphan and not try again.

I think this is a definite yes too. And something I need to backport to queens *ducks*.

We've got a lot of customer deployments hitting a situation where, nova-compute is started and for whatever reason, keystone is down or placement is down, then this orphan removal code fires and destroys the compute node but fails to delete the RP. Then, nova-compute can *never start up properly again* because during init_host, we'll create new compute node DB records and then try to create an RP for the same hypervisor_hostname that got removed as an orphan earlier, and fails with ResourceProviderCreationFailed. The customer cannot get past this point once it's in this state.

The workaround is deleting the allocations and RPs and this works OK in the absence of nova-manage heal_allocations (in queens) because we happen to be automatically refreshing allocations for ironic (in queens).

And even if we backport nova-manage heal_allocations, it's still an cumbersome manual cleanup step for customers.

What's your thought on a small separate change to swap the ordering of the compute node destroy and RP delete that is backportable to queens? I will try proposing one.

> I think this is a definite yes too. And something I need to
 > backport to queens *ducks*.
 > 
 > We've got a lot of customer deployments hitting a situation where,
 > nova-compute is started and for whatever reason, keystone is down
 > or placement is down, then this orphan removal code fires and
 > destroys the compute node but fails to delete the RP. Then,
 > nova-compute can *never start up properly again* because during
 > init_host, we'll create new compute node DB records and then try to
 > create an RP for the same hypervisor_hostname that got removed as
 > an orphan earlier, and fails with ResourceProviderCreationFailed.
 > The customer cannot get past this point once it's in this state.

That's a problem in queens because the compute node uuid is generated uniquely each time a new one is created, but starting in Rocky for ironic nodes the node uuid is used for the compute node uuid which is used for the resource provider uuid so I think that part of your problem is at least resolved in Rocky.

 > What's your thought on a small separate change to swap the ordering
 > of the compute node destroy and RP delete that is backportable to
 > queens? I will try proposing one.

So if we swap the RP delete to happen before the compute node destroy *without* the changes to the delete_resource_provider method to actually (re)raise on provider delete failure, you will have the same problem because we'd fail to destroy the provider but continue to destroy the compute node. Right? So that's not very helpful.

I think the swap is likely only useful if delete_resource_provider is also raising exceptions on failure and then you *do not* destroy the compute node if the provider deletion fails, right?

You asked about breaking apart this large change into smaller backportable pieces and for reviewability and I've been trying to think about how to do that. Naturally I'd change delete_resource_provider to raise on error first, but then we're leaking those failures in the API and in this code that is calling delete_resource_provider. So one thought is to change the call sites (API and here) to handle the exceptions even though in those patches delete_resource_provider would not yet be changed - they'd be prep patches for when delete_resource_provider is changed to raise exceptions on failure. Then maybe you do the order of operations swap in here where the provider delete happens before the compute node destroy and if the former fails the latter doesn't happen.

oslo_messaging/rpc/server.py.message:
So just fyi,

When u access fut.result() if there was an exception in that future it will raise at this point, so u might want to handle that raising its contained exception (if it has one) here.
I hadn't considered that yet, thanks.

This change means we give the possibility to provide any custom dispatcher outside oslo.messaging. I agree this gives more flexibility, but isn't dispatcher supposed to be an internal stuff and live inside oslo.messaging like executor? Wouldn't this give us some backwards compat problems in future when some custom dispatchers will die after some changes? Probably if we need some other dispatcher (like ack after processing) we could implement it and support it inside oslo messaging and switch between implementations via config like we do with drivers, matchmakers and other stuff.

For example to specify executor we pass a name (one of the existing impls) instead of passing the class itself.

Others have already implemented custom dispatchers, in Designates case, this is for handling "expected exceptions", basically wrapping the dispatch() method[1]. Mistral's is a little more involved, being a pre vs post ack thing[2]. Barbican's, while not a custom dispatcher per-se, is using a different than default dispatcher with the (now) RPCServer class[3].

Allowing some or all of the Dispatcher class to be a API consumers of o.m can extend makes a bunch of sense to me, for example, say Designate wanted to start tracking all RPC calls with StatsD, the Dispatcher class is an obvious place to put this, but baking StatsD (or Ceilometer etc) right into oslo.messaging feels wrong..

Not being able to pass this dispatcher cls into this method means we just reimplement this entire method, which caused bug 1580139 when 5.0.0 was released, as the 3 projects didn't have this helper method to hide the underlying API changes. 

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/designate/blob/master/designate/rpc.py#L178
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/master/mistral/engine/rpc.py#L49
[3]: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/barbican/tree/barbican/queue/__init__.py#n98
agree, we need dispatchers inside oslo.messaging. The dispatcher implemented by user may be useful for other users. We don't want others to reinvent one.

nova/conductor/manager.py.message: wrap_instance_event will get an InstanceActionNotFound exception if revert_snapshot_based_resize exits cleanly because the instance and it's action record in the target cell will be hard-deleted. So we likely have to avoid using the EventReporter context manager interface unless we do it with the source cell context and instance but we still need to make sure we're recording the action events in the target cell in case it fails.

Is there a follow up patch fixing this?

I guess the solution could be to record the events from the conductor task. There we have enough context about which cell we need to record the event.

We'll have to do it manually I think:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/638048/56/nova/tests/functional/test_cross_cell_migrate.py@595
on a related note as this logs a stack trace for every successful revert functional test case it increases the chance to hit the long running stestr bug :/
Yeah a) seems the cleanest. My followup question would be that then who will set the action to succeeded state when the revert succeeds?

I need to work on it. A couple of thoughts:

a) I could pass a kwarg to wrap_instance_event telling it to noop on InstanceActionNotFound on __exit__ when it's expected.

b) I could try to use the EventReporter directly but I'd likely have the same issue.

c) I could avoid the EventReporter context manager altogether and just manually create the action event on __enter__ but make __exit__ conditional on whether or not the instance still exists.

Of those 3 options, (a) is likely the cleanest.

doc/source/operations/k8s_docker_reg_man.message: 'testuser' is not a special user. this is more of an example for the next point, where 'testuser' is a regular user. In this case, admin can push to `registry.local:9001/testuser/busybox:latest` because they are admin, and testuser can push here because the username is the same as the repo name.

A local docker registry is deployed by default on the controller/master nodes as part of the StarlingX Kubernetes deployment.  

You can internally access the local docker registry at 'registry.local:9001'.

StarlingX itself stores container images in the local docker registry, although it is also available for end users to store hosted application container images.

This guide describes how to use and manage the local docker registry.

Authentication is enabled for the local docker registry. When logging in, users are authenticated using platform keystone credentials.

e.g. if using docker locally to login, 
          % docker login registry.local:9001 -u keystoneUserName -p keystonePassword

Wrt authorization:
- a platform keystone user with 'admin' role,
   can perform any/all actions on a any/all repositories
- a platform keystone user without 'admin' role,
   can perform any/all actions but ONLY on their own (self-named) repository.

e.g. The non-admin 'testuser' keystone user can only push or pull images located under registry.local:9001/testuser/... .

oops ... got it wrong ... update on authorization stuff:

Wrt authorization:
- the 'admin' platform keystone user,
   can perform any/all actions on any/all repositories
- any other platform keystone user,,
   can perform any/all actions but ONLY on their own (self-named) repository.
DELETE ... pulled info into above section.

NEW SECTION:

Using Local Docker Registry Images in Kubernetes Container Spec
------------------------------------------------------------------

When creating a pod spec or a deployment spec that uses an image from the local docker registry, you must use the full image name, including the registry, and specify an imagePullSecret with your keystone credentials.

This example procedure assumes that testuser/busybox:latest container image has been pushed to the local docker registry

Procedure:

1. Create a secret with credentials for the local docker registry.

    % kubectl create secret docker-registry testuser-registry-secret \ --docker-server=registry.local:9001 --docker-username=testuser \ --docker-password=<testuserPassword> --docker-email=noreply@windriver.com

2. Create a kubernetes deployment YAML file using the busybox container image stored in the local docker registry.  Note that 'imagePullSecret', specifying the above secret with platform keystone credentials must be specified.

% cat <<EOF > busybox.yaml apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment metadata:
   name: busybox
   namespace: default
 spec:
   progressDeadlineSeconds: 600
   replicas: 1
   selector:
     matchLabels:
       run: busybox
   template:
     metadata:
       labels:
         run: busybox
     spec:
       containers:
       - args:
         - sh

Oh, wow. It's possible to pass the sample config generator config file instead of specifying all of those namespaces on the command line, right?

The config library treats command line options as special options that can also appear in the config file, so as long as the validator command takes the --config-file option (which is implemented in the ConfigOpts class, so it should be there for free), all of the extra values can be passed that way, if the caller chooses to. We should document that, but we can do that in another patch.

I implemented the namespace listing by parsing the generator file in the integration patches [0] rather than here for multiple reasons:

A.) We need a way of allowing this verbose command for projects like cinder (or future projects that take a note from cinder) due to the way they pollute the conf file with unverifiable sections, and in real deployments (see C).

B.) Each project has different requirements for the ignore-section list. For example, nova needs to ignore both keystone_authtoken and api sections, whereas neutron only ignores keystone_authtoken. So we still need to know which sections to ignore to get correct output, but there's no way to automate discovering them. I predicted forcing spelling them out here but giving a bespoke integration per-project would prevent false-negative "bug" reports when lazily passing the conf file and generator file but no ignores.

C.) The generator file is not needed to stand up a given project and just takes up space, so real deployments don't have this file on the target node (confirmed for the largest OS IRL deployment). That's exactly where this functionality is needed. I didn't want to require changing the deployment runbooks too much. Instead, developers can use the integrations while developing (they have the file in most cases), and in production they will want to either change the runbooks and use the integrations anyway or ...

D.) alias this command for their unique case if it's really the entry point they require.

E.) I'd be willing to add it as a shortcut but I think B is a valid counterargument we should consider from a code maintenance perspective.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/429793/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/428974/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/426980/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/426408/ https://review.openstack.org/#/c/426397/

Do we eventually want this to work like a linter, where we can ignore some of these warnings but fail on others? That would be follow-up work, I'm just trying to picture what the future of the tool looks like.

How does one set an empty string? For example, to blank out logging_debug_format_suffix to avoid including location information in the log?
That's fine for a "choices" case, but there are definitely some options for which an empty value is valid. Is this going to report errors for those cases?

I guess my point is that we have options defined today for which an empty string is valid, so we need to allow them. This is another reason I think letting the Opt class do the validation makes more sense, instead of adding rules (or re-implementing checks) in this tool. We already have to do some of the sort of validation in the parsing code, let's reuse that where we can.

I think a circumspect way to handle an "empty string" option value would be to make it not required, default ''. If you want an empty string, you just leave it out of the config. If that's not tenable, we should brainstorm another approach.

The projects should be using "some_option=none" or however they want to handle that in accordance with their own tastes, because allow_no_value is not set by oslo-config as far as I can tell. For example, the way Nova configures cpu_mode, and the error you get with a blank option value:

Value for option cpu_mode is not valid: Valid values are [host-model, host-passthrough, custom, none], but found ''

Which makes sense, there's no way for anyone to tell if that's supposed to be blank or if a value is meant to be there and was missed manually or not dynamically set somewhere.

On all of these docstrings for the results param: results is a dictionary, not a list.
The return type definitions should be dropped as well, since the "return results" were dropped.

For all of these checks, there's no reason to pass the result dict in and re-assign the return value to results, because results itself is never modified at all (it's just a reference to a mutable dict, where the contents of the dict are modified). The simplest way to improve this would be to continue passing the results dict in, but drop the "return results" from them all, and skip the assignment back to results here.

That said, I could also argue that passing the results dictionary around is a bit of an anti-pattern, as it doesn't do much to enforce a contract between the validate function and the individual checks (a check could remove errors/warnings produced by another check, for example)... but I don't think that's a big deal here.

So, it turns out that positionals aren't quite being handled correctly by oslo_config.cfg

I had to make these changes to make positional=True work for a required argument:

  http://cdn.pasteraw.com/luhzytktv75uxz8qfrxgpi8bnw9v4st

Without them, two things were happening that were preventing positional=True from working correctly. Firstly, the option was being passed to argparse with nargs='?', which made it an optional argument, despite required=True in oslo.config (L60 here). Secondly, it was being validated as required in oslo.config despite being positional in argparse, which by default, is required and validated by argparse already. Probably worth filing a bug to get that fixed separately, and then we can base your patch on top of it today. If the diff above works for you (I only played with it a bit), poke me in IRC today (dolphm) and we can work out next steps.

So far, I haven't found an elegant solution to this, but oslo_config.cfg doesn't handle the difference between option names and destinations properly, at least in the case of positional arguments. So, if you change this option name to match the destination, then you can workaround the issue. Otherwise, "input-file" will appear in the argument namespace, while the required option check is checking to ensure that "input_file" is populated.

So, quick fix on this end. If there's ever a solution in oslo_config.cfg for this behavior, then you can change L59 back to input-file and it at least won't change the command's API (it's still just a positional argument).

How do we handle the situation when time on different hosts diverge for about a second or more (which is really possible in spite of syncing on time)? When you calculate latency in such case you will get negative value for example.

Agreed, I'd prefer not to have 'time.time' here. Let's not give people the false belief that clocks will always be in sync like this.

Maybe just respond with 'pong' or respond with something like what https://github.com/openstack/oslo.middleware/blob/master/oslo_middleware/healthcheck/__init__.py#L52 responds with (the json output of this for example).

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.middleware/blob/master/oslo_middleware/healthcheck/__init__.py#L295
yes, here is a problem and we need to use only one clock source.

I add to reply message (pong) some payload like time of request (ping time), hostname, service and topic names, etc. It is helpful in cases, then rpc client uses fanout exchanges in order to get state of several RPC servers at a time.

About availability it looks like a heartbeat implemented in abstract o.m. layer (RPC client/server). The idea looks good to me, but we have to take into account (and check this in testing) the performance impact. So probably we need to do that in some longer interval or by request from client (not constantly)

Latency can be calculated more or less precisely when we get the timestamp on RPCClient and then after we received reply we get timestamp (all on the same host) and then we can calculate the message round-trip latency. I'd emphasize it again that calculating something based on time.time() info from different hosts has extremely high measurement error and the result is unpredictable.

I prefer to set polling time around 5-10 mins, but it's depends at cluster size, if you want to get state of all running rpc servers. At small cluster workload on rabbit is insignificant. For example neutron-server report self state every 6 seconds. So 5 mins delay is nothing.
+1 there has to be a better way that we can do this (something say using the inbuilt functionality of the RPC server itself; which should seem to exist outside of the zeromq kind of case).

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/lba.message: you need to ensure you only pick loadbalancers generated by kuryr (with the right tagging)
If there are no tags you'll put "[]" into the description. Why not just use LBaaSv2Driver._add_tags() (possibly renaming it and making public)?

this probably should try/catch the not found exception. Also, it should get the ResourceNotReady exception and retry the deletion (otherwise some leftovers may still happen. Or at least that is what I got for namespaces while implementing the cleanup there)

When a NotFound exception is raised the deletion of the resources is ignored[1][2], so I don't think there's a need to catch it here.
Why should I retry the deletion, if when resourceNotReady exception is raised all the event will be retried?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/lbaasv2.py#L725-L736
[2] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/lbaasv2.py#L115-L135

Right about the notFound. 
But for the retry... This is not a on_present or on_delete event, but something triggered while creating the handler object, so I don't think it is retry. Plus if you have a long list you don't want to wait for the retries to delete the others as it can take a long time

Also I think this method probably expects this object, not the one from the client: https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/dfa9a392f1d3b777a68adda9f5e06d36575bf5a1/kuryr_kubernetes/objects/lbaas.py#L24

I think Luis is right about ResourceNotFound - spawning a green thread will give it a new stack, so ResourceNotFound will just go to the top of it and will never be caught by where you've run eventlet.spawn from.

If we want to do it this way, this got to be exponential and have a timeout. There's a helper function [1] and a bit overcomplicated example on how to use it [2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/1b97158c89918501e573ed42e1550ec7353d33b4/kuryr_kubernetes/utils.py#L111
[2] https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/94bb9f88044a8c7f60d45a524245441f65d59c6f/kuryr_kubernetes/watcher.py#L175
I didn't see this comment, sry. That's a good point, thanks!

Actually, with the latest version of this PS all the lbaas will have a chance to get deleted, as it's being retried for a certain amount, and if the number max of attempts is reached it will proceed to the next lbaas.

I would handle the retry in the outer loop, so that you first do a try to remove as many LBs as possible, and in the next loop you iterate over the remaining ones. This way, if octavia has problems removing one lbaas (stuck in PENDING_UPDATE), all the rest that won't have problems will be left behind

I still think it is better to iterate on the loadbalancer first and then only retry the failing ones, rather than having to wait until the failing one timeout on the number of retries and then proceed with the next one. That said, no strong opinion! Perhaps we can also create threads when running _ensure_release_lbaas so that those are run concurrently

environments/services-baremetal/neutron-.message: We want DVR by default right? I think this is not right in this case and this is why you're adding a non-dvr environment file to explicitly disable it?

For now there is a mess around files and naming.
We have:

./environments/services-baremetal/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml
./environments/services-baremetal/neutron-ovn-dvr-ha.yaml
./environments/services/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml
./environments/services/neutron-ovn-dvr-ha.yaml

Because of flipped DVR flag in Rocky the:
./environments/services/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml
./environments/services-baremetal/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml
Now acts the same as DVR (but shouldn't).

So what we decided on IRC a few weeks ago is to drop those two in the next release and add deprecation note:
./environments/services/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml
./environments/services-baremetal/neutron-ovn-ha.yaml

And add new templates that will have proper naming with DVR disabled explicitly:
./environments/services-baremetal/neutron-ovn-non-dvr-ha.yaml
./environments/services/neutron-ovn-non-dvr-ha.yaml
I mean, if we have dvr disabled here and then we create another template called 'non-dvr-....yaml' aren't we duplicating things?

DVR is set as default here:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/environments/services/neutron-ovn-dvr-ha.yaml#L29
And the template name is neutron-ovn-dvr-ha.yaml.

So as we discussed on IRC we would like to have DVR in the template name.
For other templates we disable it (previous behavior).

Now that OVN is the default, I wonder if we should reconsider adding things to environment files on a given release that are already the default in the heat templates. Having stuff duplicated is a bit of tech debt even if it isn't used by anyone and we need to be careful to keep everything in sync. Case in point, the default service and plugin extensions noted here are not the same as the defaults in the heat templates.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Is it proper for an non-admin tenant to get ports from other tenant?

I did retest this with a user account that had _member_ only in multiple projects, and the API response did only return ports from the currently scoped project, so my guess was wrong. However, an account with the admin role would still be able all the ports. I updated the commit message accordingly.
For a non-admin, it could be proper if the user account had a role assigned in multiple tenants. In the case when we actually ran into an issue, it happened to be an account which had the admin role.

It al depends on the downstream RBAC rules in place when running the API tests.  We are seeing that we need to run primary  user as admin due to our changes in RBAC rules and the need to still test the APIs.  We are thinking of submitting a spec to split the credit manager so the primary and alt user can have their own roles assigned for dynamic creds and grouped  apart in preprovision creds so you can change your usr roles according to the RBAC implementation both upstream and downstream. Primary could be admin and Alt be member when testing thing like transfers and private images.

This is independent from Phil's [change but would like and feedback before we submit the spec.  We will also bring it up on IRC office hours.  

Thank in advance for any input.
this can be fixed in separate patch as mentioned in my reply to previous PS comment.

i guess it makes more sense to infer NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER from IPSEC_PACKAGE only when the former isn't explicitly set. how do you think?
Sorry, I have not noticed that vendor driver config. You are right, I will update.

Thanks for review. If we determine  NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER firstly, we hard to know which IPSEC_PACKAGE to use. We should make OS install strongswan using VPN:strongswan:neutron_vpnaas.services.vpn.service_drivers.ipsec.IPsecVPNDriver:default and OS install libreswan using another.
This is a similar behavior in L49~L55.
Do you think so?

there are out of tree drivers like midonet.
midonet uses NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER="VPN:Midonet:midonet.neutron.services.vpn.service_drivers.midonet_ipsec.MidonetIPsecVPNDriver:default"
it doesn't use l3 agent. (thus IPSEC_PACKAGE is not specified or used there)

because IPSEC_PACKAGE has the default value (strongswan), this change would break configurations like the above, right?

IPSEC_PACKAGE is an agent config. it's a bit abuse to use it for plugin settings. personally i don't see what's wrong with leaving it to users' responsibility to set NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER appropriately. (to IPsecVPNDriver in your case)

i don't insist if it's used only when NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER is not explicitly set though.
eg. switching the default value of NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER according to IPSEC_PACKAGE in devstack/settings.

how do you think?

I like yamamoto's idea to configure NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER in devstack/settings based on IPSEC_PACKAGE.

Regarding the point that IPSEC_PACKAGE is an agent config, I am okay to use it for plugin settings. We need to configure the plugin based on which IPsec package is used, so I think it is not limited to an agent config.

devstack/settings.message: We need to honor NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER configured in local.conf (as the previous code does).

There is no need to check the existing DEFAULT_SERVICE_PROVIDER as NEUTRON_VPNAAS_PROVIDER is used if a user would like to specify it.

In addition, the only difference is "openswan" and "strongswan" and this field in service_provider configuration is just a name.
It is better to clarify it.

My suggestion is to change L.11-15 to:

 function _get_service_provider {
     local ipsec_package=$1
     local name driver

     driver="neutron_vpnaas.services.vpn.service_drivers.ipsec.IPsecVPNDriver"
     if [ "$ipsec_package" = "libreswan" ]; then
         name="openswan"
     else
         name="strongswan"
     fi
     echo "VPN:${name}:${driver}:default"
 }

 if [ -z "$NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER" ]; then
     NEUTRON_VPNAAS_SERVICE_PROVIDER=$(_get_service_provider $IPSEC_PACKAGE)
 fi

The first if-clause does the same as ":-" substitution.

Yes, the first if-clause does same as FOO=${FOO:-default}.
And DEFAULT_SERVICE_PROVIDER seems import a new variable.
Thanks for your suggestion, I will update.
